message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and laboratory results suggest that he has obstructive jaundice, which can be caused by a distended gallbladder. Surface nodularity of the liver and multifocal dilation and stricturing of intra- and extrahepatic ducts suggest liver cirrhosis or cholangiocarcinoma, which are less likely in this scenario. Pancreatic pseudocyst may be a complication of acute pancreatitis, but there are no signs of recurrent acute pancreatitis in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest obstructive jaundice, which can be caused by a distended gallbladder due to gallstones. Surface nodularity of the liver and multifocal dilation and stricturing of intra- and extrahepatic ducts are more likely to be seen in liver cirrhosis or cholangiocarcinoma. Pancreatic pseudocysts are fluid collections in or around the pancreas, which are not likely to cause obstructive jaundice.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with jaundice and elevated liver enzymes, suggesting possible obstruction of the bile duct. A distended gallbladder may indicate cholelithiasis or cholecystitis, which can cause obstruction of the common bile duct. Surface nodularity of the liver, pancreatic pseudocyst, and multifocal dilation and stricturing of intra- and extrahepatic ducts do not fit the patient’s symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and laboratory findings suggest obstructive jaundice which can be caused by a distended gallbladder. Surface nodularity of the liver and multifocal dilation and stricturing of intra- and extrahepatic ducts suggest liver cirrhosis and primary sclerosing cholangitis respectively, which are not likely causes in this case. Pancreatic pseudocyst is not associated with jaundice.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and laboratory studies suggest obstructive jaundice, which can be caused by gallstones or a tumor. A distended gallbladder is indicative of gallstones. Surface nodularity of the liver is seen in cirrhosis or malignancy, pancreatic pseudocysts are seen in chronic pancreatitis, and multifocal dilation and stricturing of intra- and extrahepatic ducts is seen in primary sclerosing cholangitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory studies suggest obstructive jaundice caused by a stone lodged in the common bile duct, leading to a distended gallbladder. The other options are not consistent with the findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest bile duct obstruction, which could be caused by a distended gallbladder. Abdominal imaging would help confirm the diagnosis and identify any other abnormalities. Surface nodularity of the liver could suggest cirrhosis, which is not consistent with the patient's history, while multifocal dilation and stricturing of intra- and extrahepatic ducts could suggest cholangiocarcinoma, which would be less likely given the patient's presentation. Pancreatic pseudocyst would not be expected to cause this pattern of liver function test abnormalities.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms, past medical history, and laboratory results suggest obstructive jaundice with possible cholecystitis. A distended gallbladder would be the most likely finding on abdominal imaging. Surface nodularity of the liver could suggest cirrhosis, which is not supported by the current history and lab results. Pancreatic pseudocyst and multifocal dilation and stricturing of ducts would not be expected findings in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and laboratory studies suggest obstructive jaundice, which is commonly caused by a distended gallbladder or choledocholithiasis. Surface nodularity of the liver is a sign of cirrhosis, pancreatic pseudocyst would not cause jaundice, and multifocal dilation and stricturing of intra- and extrahepatic ducts would suggest primary sclerosing cholangitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and elevated bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase levels suggest obstructive jaundice, which is most commonly caused by a stone in the common bile duct or by cancer of the pancreas or bile ducts. An abdominal ultrasound or CT would show a distended gallbladder, indicating obstruction of the common bile duct. Surface nodularity of the liver is seen in cirrhosis, pancreatic pseudocyst would present as a mass in the pancreas, and multifocal dilation and stricturing of intra- and extrahepatic ducts would be seen in primary sclerosing cholangitis.
